questions.title: Question 1 for Class 191023
questions.main: If the air temperature is close to the dew point would the relative humidity be high or low? Explain.
questions.answer: At the  dew point air will be saturated.  The closer temperature is to the dew point the closer it is to saturation.

questions.title: Question 2 for Class 191023
questions.main: As the difference between the air temperature and the dew point increases the relative humidity:

mcq.option: C) remains constant at a value less than 100%
D) remains constant and equal to 100%

questions.title: Question 3 for Class 191023
questions.main: The temperature to which air must be cooled in order to become saturated is the:

questions.title: Question 4 for Class 191023
questions.main: As the air temperature increases with no addition of water vapor to the air the dew point will:

mcq.option: D) increase and become equal to the air temperature

questions.title: Question 5 for Class 191023
questions.main: In the vertical the pressure gradient force points ____ and gravity points ____.
questions.answer: D) away from the earth, toward the earth

mcq.option: A) toward the earth, away from the earth
B) toward the earth, toward the earth
C) away from the earth, away from the earth
D) away from the earth, toward the earth

questions.title: Question 6 for Class 191023
questions.main: Explain how dew frozen dew and visible frost form.
questions.answer: Dew: when the air cools to the dew point - the temperature at which saturation occurs. Frozen dew: If the air temperature should drop to freezing or below the dew will freeze becoming tiny beads of ice. Visible frost: forms on cold clear calm mornings when the dew-point temperature is at or below freezing. When the air temperature cools to the dew point (now called the frost point) and further cooling occurs water vapor can change directly to ice without becoming a liquid first - a process called deposition.

questions.main: Describe the atmospheric conditions that are necessary for the formation of advection fog
questions.answer: Air passing over a colder and moist surface will both be cooled toward its dew point and have moisture added raising the dew point toward the temperature.""

mcq.option: D) impossible to tell from the information given

questions.title: Question 13 for Class 191023
questions.main: Describe the atmospheric conditions that are necessary for the formation of radiation fog
questions.answer: Radiational cooling of the surface lowers the temperature to the dew point temperature.

questions.answer: B) more rapidly in the vertical direction than in the horizontal

mcq.option: A) more rapidly in the horizontal direction than in the vertical
B) more rapidly in the vertical direction than in the horizontal
C) at the same rate in the horizontal and vertical directions
D) more rapidly in the vertical over land than over the ocean

questions.title: Question 17 for Class 191023
questions.main: Nighttime temperatures rarely drop below the dew point temperature because:
questions.answer: C) at saturation, latent heat of condensation is released into the air

mcq.option: A) the dew will absorb all the heat
B) saturation vapor pressures always increase at night
C) at saturation, latent heat of condensation is released into the air
D) both saturation vapor pressures always increase at night, and at saturation, latent heat of condensation is released into the air

questions.title: Question 21 for Class 191023
questions.main: Which of the following sets of conditions would produce a cumulus cloud with the lowest base?

B) air temperature 90¬∞F, dew point temperature 40¬∞F
C) air temperature 90¬∞F, dew point temperature 60¬∞F
D) air temperature 90¬∞F, dew point temperature 20¬∞F

questions.title: Question 23 for Class 191023
questions.main: How does the weather usually change along a dryline? Since hot dry air is often located behind (to the west) of a dryline why are drylines not classified as warm fronts?
questions.answer: The dew points change markedly.  Dry lines separate dry and moist air rather than warm and cool air.

questions.title: Question 24 for Class 191023
questions.main: List two primary ways in which fog forms.
questions.answer: Fog forms (1) by cooling - air is cooled below its saturation point (dew point) and (2) by evaporation and mixing - water vapor is added to the air by evaporation and the moist air mixes with relatively dry air.

questions.title: Question 25 for Class 191023
questions.main: Suppose it is a winter night and at about 11 pm the air cools to the dew-point temperature and a thick radiation fog develops. If the air continues to cool during the night in 5 hours the dew point temperature will probably:
questions.answer: A) decrease as the air becomes drier

mcq.option: A) decrease as the air becomes drier
B) decrease as the air becomes moister
C) increase as the air becomes drier
D) increase as the air becomes moister

questions.title: Question 26 for Class 191023
questions.main: If the air temperature in a room is 70 degrees F the saturation vapor pressure is 25 mb  the dew point temperature is 45 degrees F and the actual vapor pressure is 10 mb then the  relative humidity must be near ____ percent.

questions.title: Question 27 for Class 191023
questions.main: Describe the Milankovitch theory of climatic change by explaining how each of the three cycles alters the amount of solar energy reaching the earth.
questions.answer: The Milankovitch theory of climatic changeacknowledges that the earth's orbit changes in three ways over time:  1. The orbit moves from roughly circular to elliptical.  An elliptical orbit harvests less sunlight over the year.  2. The tilt of the eart wobbles pointing now toward the North Star it will point elsewhere over time changing the time of year that the earth is closest the sun.  3. The tilt of the earth varies from 21.5 degrees  to 24.5 degrees  thus changing the degree of seasonality.

questions.title: Question 31 for Class 191023
questions.main: At midnight in a shallow layer of air near the ground the air temperature is 44 degrees F and the dew point temperature is 36 degrees F. If the air cools at a rate of 2 degrees F per hour until the dew point is reached and at a rate of 1 degrees F per hour thereafter what will be the temperature and atmospheric conditions at 6:00 am?
questions.answer: E) the temperature will be 34¬∞F and only dew will be present

mcq.option: A) the temperature will be 34¬∞F and no condensation will be present
B) the temperature will be 32¬∞F with frost and frozen dew present
C) the temperature will be 32¬∞F and only frost will be present
D) the temperature will be 32¬∞F and only frozen dew will be present
E) the temperature will be 34¬∞F and only dew will be present

questions.title: Question 37 for Class 191023
questions.main: On a weather map sharp changes in temperature humidity and wind direction are marked by:

questions.title: Question 38 for Class 191023
questions.main: What conditions are necessary for upwelling to occur along the west coast of North America? How does upwelling influence the formation of fog?
questions.answer: Northerly winds along the West Coast cause upwelling. As the deeper colder water rises to the surface it cools the air directly above the water. Fog commonly occurs as the surface air cools to its dew point temperature.

questions.answer: A) enhance the atmospheric greenhouse effect

B) weaken the atmospheric greenhouse effect
C) are often caused by the atmospheric greenhouse effect
D) have no effect on the atmospheric greenhouse effect

questions.title: Question 42 for Class 191023
questions.main: Wind machines can prevent surface air temperatures from reaching extremely low readings by:
questions.answer: C) mixing surface air with air directly above

mcq.option: A) blowing smoke over an orchard or field
B) increasing the evaporation rate from fruits and vegetables
C) mixing surface air with air directly above
D) reducing the rate of cooling by evaporation
E) increasing the likelihood of condensation on fruits and vegetables

questions.title: Question 43 for Class 191023

questions.answer: A) enhancement of the greenhouse effect by the fog cloud

mcq.option: A) enhancement of the greenhouse effect by the fog cloud
B) trapping of smoke and dust by the water vapor
C) calm winds that accompany fog

questions.main: Explain why barometric pressure usually falls with the approach of a cold front or occluded front.
questions.answer: A cold front is a trough of low pressure.

questions.main: A surface LOW pressure area that moves from south to north directly east of your home would most likely produce winds that shift from:
questions.answer: E) NE to N to NW

B) SE to E to SW
C) N to NE to E
D) W to NW to N
E) NE to N to NW

questions.title: Question 49 for Class 191023
questions.main: Suppose it is snowing outside and the air is saturated.  The air temperature and dew  point are both 15 degrees F and the actual vapor pressure is 3 mb. If this air is brought  indoors and warmed to 75 degrees F what would the relative humidity of this air be

questions.title: Question 50 for Class 191023
questions.main: On an upper-level chart is cold air aloft generally associated with low or high pressure? What about warm air aloft ?
questions.answer: Cold air aloft: low pressure.  Warm air aloft: high pressure.
